ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Heat/Mass Transfer, a lot of math skills, Engineering numbers, Conduction/Convection modelling, Navier Stokes Equations
I learned topics in heat and mass transfer, as well as an introduction to tensor calculus and review of multivariable calculus.
A lot of mathematical skills and analysis of heat and mass transport problems.
In this course, I developed my knowledge of transport phenomena, which includes things such as heat and mass transfer. I also learned important math techniques such as separation of variables.
Learned about diffusive and conductive mass and heat transfer

We practiced a lot of nondimensionalization and we learned governing equations for heat, mass and momentum transfers. We also used A LOT of differential equations and practiced various methods for solving them.
I learned how to solve problems in transport and was able to build off of knowledge from last semester.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths
-Very organized lecture notes
-PHENOMENAL TA
-Organized Lecture

Weaknesses
-Very dry material
-Professor is not super engaging
-Professor sometimes assumes we know more than we know
-SUPER HARD material

The curriculum in this course was entirely too difficult. Tensor calculus is hard on its own, and being expected to use it for proofs after one week of summarizing the main topics was overwhelming. The in-class problems were much more advanced than what students in a typical Mass Transport (as this course is called at other universities) class solve, and the homework was impossible to do without going to recitation and following the TA's every step. I tried getting help from my math major friends on the calculations, and everything was unfamiliar to them. I even asked real engineers and none of them knew how to solve these problems, as they were way too theoretical. This really should have been a PhD class, not an undergraduate course. 
I have to give the professor some credit, however. Dr. Haji-Akbari was aware that the subject matter was very difficult, and so he posted detailed notes for every one of the lectures -- the only way I could make sense of anything in this class was sitting down with a friend and spending a few hours digesting every single line of each lecture. He was also very accommodating in allowing us to take the exams from home with open notes and giving us a generous curve, which is a policy that definitely needs to remain after the pandemic ends. So, to improve the course, I would recommend seriously simplifying the curriculum. Even if we cover fewer topics, I promise we will get more out of it if we actually understand the material.

The professor is super accommodating and goes a long way to make sure that we are doing well in the class. I think he knows that the class is hard, and this is also a hard time to be studying such a hard course. The notes were incredible.
I think that Amir is a good Professor. He sometimes goes fast, but his lecture notes are so detailed that I can always go back to them if I get lost in class.
The lecture notes were very detailed and very helpful in understanding the material

Strengths - It built a lot on differential equations and I felt like I got to apply a lot of principles I learned in that class. Lecture notes were also super helpful, as was recitation and the professors office hours.

Weaknesses - Towards the end, we covered a lot of dense material really quickly and I never got the chance to really process it.

Strengths of the course are that discussion sections were helpful in understanding the problem sets. The topics were very interesting and fundamental to chemical engineering. A weakness is that lectures were sometimes confusing.
Very organized!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The format worked well

The lecture notes posted on Canvas were key to success in this class, and virtual recitation sessions worked quite well. In fact, I think that the flexibility provided by having a recorded, virtual recitation was very helpful, and that this should remain after Covid ends as well. I found it very useful to be able to come back and rewatch part of a recitation as I was doing my homework, too. And, recitations are usually in the evenings, and it was quite convenient to be able to stay in my room after dinner and still be able to attend recitation.
Recorded lectures are great.
The usage of zoom was very convenient but for this subject, it made learning a bit harder. Holding office hours quite often and the effort the teacher put in really helped.
I think that having a component with more in-class discussion would have been nice because his lectures did get dry sometimes.
I liked the live virtual lectures which allowed students to stop the professor and ask questions

Professor Haji-Akbari was very empathetic with respect to deadlines for homework and exam dates. There were two exams in the course, both of which were take-home style with 42 hours to complete them. He always aimed to schedule them so as to minimize conflicting dates with exams in our other classes.
Virtual recitations were amazing. I loved that recitations were now recorded, which gave me much more flexibility.
Discussion sections worked very well and helped substitute for in-person office hours in terms of the problem sets.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: NO. Very dry. Only take if required.
This course is required for chemical engineering majors.
I doubt you would even consider this class if you are not a Chemical Engineering major, but if you want a challenge, go ahead.
Not unless you have to take it, it was quite difficult.

I would recommend this course to another student, but it really doesn't make sense to take unless you are an engineering major. While I enjoyed the topics, there is a lot of math and tons of equations. Also, the class does take up a lot of time.
If you're interested in mass and heat transfer, then yes
You likely taking this course if you're a ChemE major, so there isn't much of an option there.
The material is very specific to Chem E majors, so Id only recommend for those students. Its very challenging, one of the hardest classes Ive taken at Yale.
Yes, I would recommend this course and it is also a major requirement.

Lecture is live and recorded

live virtual lectures with professor and recitation sessions with TA, both of which were recorded
Live discussion sections
